sub_concept: Initial ventilator setup for hypercapnic respiratory failure
stem: A patient with COPD exacerbation is intubated for acute hypercapnic respiratory failure. Which initial ventilator strategy is most appropriate?
option_a: Low tidal volume with moderate rate allowing longer expiratory time
option_b: High tidal volume with short expiratory time
option_c: Low rate with high tidal volume
option_d: Very high PEEP with low rate
rationale_correct: COPD patients require lung-protective tidal volumes and sufficient expiratory time to avoid air trapping.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because it balances ventilation and prevents dynamic hyperinflation. | B: Short expiratory time worsens auto-PEEP. | C: High tidal volumes increase barotrauma risk. | D: Excess PEEP can worsen hyperinflation.
common_trap: Ignoring air trapping risk in COPD.

stem: An intubated patient has PaCO2 40 mm Hg and PaO2 55 mm Hg on FiO2 0.80 and PEEP 5. Which ventilator adjustment best improves oxygenation?
rationale_correct: PaCO2 is normal, so ventilation is adequate. Oxygenation improves most directly with increased PEEP.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct oxygenation lever. | B: Rate affects CO2 primarily. | C: Flow change not primary oxygenation fix. | D: Higher VT risks lung injury.
common_trap: Treating CO2 when O2 is problem.
exam_logic: Use correct lever for physiologic issue.

stem: ABG: pH 7.28, PaCO2 60 mm Hg, PaO2 92 mm Hg on FiO2 0.40. What ventilator change best corrects the primary problem?
rationale_correct: Elevated PaCO2 indicates inadequate ventilation; increasing rate increases minute ventilation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct ventilation adjustment. | B: PEEP affects oxygenation. | C: Oxygenation already adequate. | D: Not primary CO2 lever.

stem: A ventilated COPD patient becomes hypotensive. Flow-time waveform shows expiratory flow not returning to baseline before next breath. What is most likely occurring?
rationale_correct: Incomplete exhalation before next breath indicates dynamic hyperinflation and intrinsic PEEP.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct waveform sign. | B: Leak would show different alarm pattern. | C: Compliance issue shows different waveform pattern. | D: Hypotension linked to intrathoracic pressure rise.
exam_logic: Waveform pattern recognition is high yield.

stem: Which statement best describes volume assist-control ventilation?
option_a: Every breath receives full preset tidal volume
option_c: Pressure varies to maintain constant pressure
option_d: Tidal volume changes with compliance automatically
rationale_correct: In volume assist-control, each triggered breath delivers preset tidal volume.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct AC definition. | B: That describes pressure support. | C: That describes pressure control. | D: Volume AC delivers set VT.

stem: In pressure control ventilation, which variable is set and remains constant during inspiration?
rationale_correct: Pressure control delivers constant preset inspiratory pressure; tidal volume varies.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct PC property. | B: VT varies. | C: Minute ventilation varies. | D: Expiratory flow not controlled variable.

stem: A patient with ARDS is on VT 10 mL/kg. Plateau pressure is 35 cm H2O. What is the best change?
option_b: Increase tidal volume to improve oxygenation
rationale_correct: Plateau pressure >30 indicates risk of ventilator-induced lung injury; reduce tidal volume.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct lung-protective strategy. | B: Increases injury risk. | C: Rate not primary problem. | D: PEEP removal may worsen oxygenation.

stem: How is plateau pressure accurately measured?
rationale_correct: Plateau pressure requires inspiratory pause to eliminate flow.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct measurement technique. | B: Not related. | C: Does not measure plateau directly. | D: Mode change unnecessary.

sub_concept: High peak pressure normal plateau meaning
stem: A patient has peak pressure 45 cm H2O and plateau 22 cm H2O. What is most likely cause?
rationale_correct: Large difference between peak and plateau suggests airway resistance problem.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct bronchospasm or obstruction pattern. | B: Compliance issue elevates plateau. | C: ARDS raises plateau. | D: VT low would reduce pressures.

stem: Which finding best suggests readiness for spontaneous breathing trial?
option_a: Stable hemodynamics and adequate oxygenation on low support
rationale_correct: Weaning requires stability and low support settings.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct readiness indicator. | B: High PEEP not ready. | C: High FiO2 not ready. | D: Severe acidosis not stable.
